newsitem.title: USA: Computer scientists discover new largest prime number.
newsitem.headline: Computer scientists discover new largest prime number.

text.p: Computer scientists at Cray Research have discovered the largest-known prime number, with 378,632 digits filling about 12 newspaper pages, Cray said on Tuesday.
Prime numbers can be divided evenly only by themselves and one. Examples include 2, 3, 5, 7 and 11. The new number was discovered at the company's facility in Chippewa Falls, Wisconsin.
According to Cray, the Greek mathematician Euclid proved that there is an infinite number of prime numbers, but they do not occur in a regular sequence and there is no formula for generating them.

Cray said finding prime numbers is a "torture test" for supercomputers, which helps researchers learn new techniques for speeding up mathematical operations. The process requires randomly generating and testing millions of numbers.
The number itself, however, is seen as simply a mathematical curiosity.
"I'd have to say that it's not really significant at all for any practical use," said Christopher Colby, a computer science professor at Loyola University in Chicago.
"I would use it to get more research grants, perhaps," Colby said.
Cray, a unit of Silicon Graphics Inc, said it had discovered the previously largest prime number as well, which had 258,716 digits.
